primary_topic: SuperAgent chat session — multi-agent parallel research with 12+ concurrent agents executing web search/scrape tasks
design_decisions_found: Multi-agent parallel execution pattern (12 concurrent subagents)
Plan/node/task hierarchical decomposition
Web search + content extraction as primary research tools
NDJSON event stream with discriminated union event types (22 types)
Browser-use / human-in-the-loop interrupt patterns
schemas_or_data: PlanSet { plans: Record<string, Plan> }
Plan { plan_tasks: Record<string, PlanTask>, status: LOADING|ERROR|SUCCESS }
StreamEvent union (22 types: stream_start, task_update, node_tool_event, node_report_preview_*, message_delta, references_found, done, ERROR, etc.)
Pending source schema (plan_id, plan_set_id, plan_task_id, title, type: WEB|DOCUMENT|CODING_AGENT)
key_insights: Superagent uses explicit plan/node/task identifiers in streaming, not implicit event correlation
Web research sources are tracked as first-class 'pending sources' before completion
Run ledger includes both agent orchestration events AND chat streaming events (dual stream pattern)
Multi-agent execution model: decomposer (planner) → 12 parallel executors (research agents) → synthesizer (report generator)
key_signals: 12 parallel agents, web search + scrape tools, decomposition before dispatch
NDJSON streaming with typed events, plan/node/tool hierarchy explicit in payloads
Pending sources tracked, delivered as entity references in final synthesis
Plan → Reports → Deliverables pipeline (3-4 async phases)
Event streaming dual stream: chat output + orchestration/run events

primary_topic: Production SuperAgent UI bundle — complete Next.js app with chat interface, report rendering, and GML component system
design_decisions_found: Custom GML (Gradient Markup Language) for report rendering with 18 tags
Dual rendering path: GML for chat preview, React/JSX for v0.app exports
CVA (class-variance-authority) for component variant management
Plotly.js for chat charts, Recharts in v0.app exports
Structural 'healer' system that auto-repairs malformed LLM-generated GML markup
schemas_or_data: GML tag registry (18 tags: gml-row, gml-primarycolumn, gml-sidebarcolumn, gml-chartcontainer, gml-infoblockmetric, gml-infoblockevent, gml-gradientinsightbox, etc.)
Citation system with entity-bound references and hover previews
Plotly data schemas: chart type enum (bar, scatter, line, donut, candlestick, etc.), layout object, data traces, error bars
HSLA color palette: 6-stop teal (186° hue, varying lightness), green accent (103°), red error gradients
key_insights: GML is a domain-specific markup language, not generic HTML—strict tag registry with width constraints (sidebar components CAN'T appear in primary column)
Healer pattern: LLM output often malformed; renderer hoists/removes widgets to correct parents automatically
Seasons Sans font (A-Type foundry, 12 weights including non-standard 440/550/580/650) custom-licensed for SuperAgent
Dual design system support: base theme (Geist, teal palette) + redesign theme (Seasons Sans, warm white + black, HSLA alpha scale)
Report widgets are highly uniform: 506-685 LOC per widget suggests output token budgeting per component
key_signals: GML: 18-tag domain language with structural validation, citation binding, responsive layout
Healer: auto-repair malformed LLM markup (hoist/remove pattern)
Plotly.js in chat, Recharts in exports, no D3 except in advanced reports
Seasons Sans font: proprietary, 12 weights, A-Type foundry licensed
Two-tier theme: Geist (base) + Seasons Sans (redesign), OKLCH + HSLA color models

primary_topic: Master index of SuperAgent analysis — synthesizes chat UI reverse engineering, three v0.app report exports, and generation pipeline forensics
design_decisions_found: v0.app is the code generation engine; SuperAgent is the orchestrator/product layer
Three distinct architectural patterns observed across three reports (monolithic → coordinator → four-tier)
Frozen 181K shadcn/ui template bundle with 8 custom SuperAgent components + modifications to 45 stock components
Atomic export pattern: all files written simultaneously with identical timestamp (not interactive development)
Multi-agent parallel execution proven via git history in Report A (standards → 4 parallel agents → integration phase)
schemas_or_data: Comparative table: Reports A/B/C architecture, viz libraries, shadcn bundle, custom hooks, animations, fonts, TSX LOC, zip size
Template bundle: 181,174 bytes (byte-for-byte identical in Reports B & C), 57 shadcn/ui components, 8 custom SuperAgent additions
Generation pipeline stages (0-7): Research/RAG → Template assembly → Architecture decision → Theme generation → Layout primitives → Content sections → Widget generation → Atomic export
key_insights: SuperAgent's product layer selects architecture mode (monolithic/coordinator/four-tier) based on content complexity or time evolution
Report A (older?) uses 3-component bundle; Reports B & C (newer) use full 57-component frozen bundle shipped regardless of utilization (85% unused components)
Template bundle is byte-identical across reports, confirming it's a frozen export from v0.app, not generated per-report
Cross-file data consistency (MSFT $281.7B in 5+ files across Report C) proves shared data brief feeds all downstream generators
Vestigial artifacts prove code generation pipeline: `[v0] Failed to load D3` console logs, unused `styles/globals.css`, duplicated `use-mobile` hook
key_signals: v0.app engine + SuperAgent orchestrator separation proven by watermarks and atomic exports
Three architecture patterns: monolithic (A) → coordinator (B) → four-tier composition (C)
Frozen 181K template bundle confirmed byte-for-byte in B & C, proving v0.app exports
Multi-agent execution: Report A git history shows 4 named agents in parallel (standards → 4 executors → integration)
Atomic export: all files same timestamp, no build artifacts, pragmatic error-ignoring config (next.config: ignoreBuildErrors)

primary_topic: Deep dive into Report B (DMN-Ontology Decision Management System) — 11 interactive visualization components, Royal Blue Corporate design system, two-tier architecture
design_decisions_found: Two-tier report architecture: coordinator page (567 LOC) + flat component layer (11 components, 8,658 lines total)
Royal Blue Corporate design system: #1e3a8a primary, #dbeafe light blue accent, Inter + Geist Mono + Playfair Display fonts
Hub-and-spoke visualization highlighting: Set<string> for O(1) membership checks across multiple viz components
Recursive upstream/downstream path tracing for metric cascade (implicit graph algorithm)
SVG animated particles using `<animateMotion>` for 'data flowing' visual metaphor
schemas_or_data: 11 visualization components: LineChartDemo, BarChartDemo, ScatterPlotDemo, HistogramDemo, HeatmapDemo, SankeyDemo, TreemapDemo, ForcedDirectedGraphDemo, MetricCascade, etc.
Design tokens: Royal Blue (#1e3a8a), Light Blue Accent (#dbeafe), no custom shadows, animation via CSS transitions
Component-level state management: React useState + useMemo, no external state library
key_insights: Report B uses Recharts + custom D3 (force graph, sankey, treemap) — no single charting library dogmatism
Hub-and-spoke pattern proves deliberate UX design (shared state across vizs), not accidental coupling
Recursive path tracing suggests domain-specific requirements (knowledge graphs, decision trees) not generic components
Two-tier architecture is simpler than Report C's four-tier, suggesting older generation or simpler domain
Design system is minimal (no custom shadows, no animations outside of transitions), suggesting tight output budgeting
superseded_by: REPORT_C_ANALYSIS.md (Report C shows evolution to four-tier architecture, Soft Brutalism design, uniform widget sizing)
key_signals: Two-tier: coordinator + flat components (simpler than Report C)
Royal Blue Corporate theme: minimal (no shadows, basic fonts), hex-only colors
Recharts + D3 hybrid: Sankey, treemap, forced-directed graph (domain-specific viz)
Hub-and-spoke state pattern: Set<string> for O(1) membership in visualization highlighting
8,658 LOC across 11 components = ~786 lines per component average (vs Report C's ~650 tighter budget)

primary_topic: Complete GML markup language specification — 18 tags, layout patterns, citation system, structural healing/validation rules
design_decisions_found: GML width constraints: sidebar components (metrics, events, tickers) MUST be in gml-sidebarcolumn; primary components (charts, blockquotes) in gml-primarycolumn
Healing behavior: 'hoist' (move misplaced element to correct ancestor) or 'remove' (strip invalid element)
Citation architecture: identifier-based lookup, entity-bound references, hover/click to expand
Container queries (@md, @3xl) for responsive layout switching (mobile → desktop)
Metric cards with sentiment: 'good' (green #006400), 'bad' (red #B10F41), 'warning' (amber #AF6002), 'neutral' (gray #41454D)
schemas_or_data: GML tag widths: blockquote→[primary], chartcontainer→[primary], infoblockmetric→[sidebar], halfcolumn→[full_row], etc.
Healing logic (L function): walk AST, check width constraints, hoist to valid ancestor or remove
Plotly color palette: 6-stop teal (HSLA), green accent (103, 40%, 43%), red error gradients with alpha
Citation schema: citation_identifier (entity UUID), external_url, title, provider (brave/firecrawl/polygon), retrieved_at
Chart data schemas: type enum (bar, scatter, line, donut, candlestick, histogram, box, bubble, stacked_bar, clustered_column)
key_insights: Healing system is the 'safety net' for LLM generation — model output doesn't need perfect structure, just right components in roughly right places
Width constraints are not soft guidelines; they're enforced via healer and define valid layouts (container patterns)
Citation system decouples rendering from provenance — citations are just identifiers, lookup happens at render time
Sentiment colors hard-coded per component type (not data-driven), suggesting preset variants, not arbitrary theming
Container queries enable responsive layout without breakpoint-specific CSS classes (cleaner, more maintainable)
key_signals: 18-tag GML language with strict width constraints, healing/validation system (hoist/remove)
Healability core to design: LLM output often malformed; renderer auto-corrects structure
Citation system: entity-bound, identifier-based, lookup at render time (not embedding)
Plotly charts in GML, Recharts in exports (dual rendering path)
Container queries (@md, @3xl) for responsive layout, no viewport breakpoint classes

primary_topic: Complete CSS token extraction from production SuperAgent bundles — Tailwind v4 theme, redesign variant, GML component styling, 277 color variables
design_decisions_found: Tailwind v4 CSS-first config (no tailwind.config.js), @layer theme/base/components/utilities structure
OKLCH + HSLA dual color system: OKLCH for standard palette (22 families, 11 shades each), Hex for neutral/semantic
Redesign theme via data-theme='redesign' attribute: warm white bg, near-black text, HSLA alpha scale for contrast
Custom shadow system: 3-tier low/low-hover/high, aliased to TW scale (2xs=low, md=low-hover, lg/xl=high)
GML component CSS: primarycolumn/prose typography rules, responsive gap/padding, blockquote/list/table styling
schemas_or_data: 277 CSS custom properties: 231 OKLCH colors, 45 Hex, 1 var() alias
Redesign token system: --warm-white, --black, --purple-accent, alpha-based neutrals (4%, 8%, 16%, 24%, 32%, 48%, 64%, 72%, 78%, 80%)
Typography scale: --text-xs through --text-9xl (9 levels), custom --tracking-tighter-2/-3 variants
Shadow system: --shadow-2xs/sm/md/lg/xl/2xl with aliases for low/hover/high tiers, --shadow-md-glow custom
Container sizes: --container-3xs (16rem) through --container-7xl (80rem), non-standard like --container-3xl (48rem)
key_insights: Redesign theme is a complete style override (fonts, colors, shadows) via single data-theme attribute, not CSS variables switching (production-grade theming)
OKLCH color system ensures consistent lightness across hue families (better perceptual uniformity than Hex),  but Hex reserved for strategic colors (errors, semantic)
GML prose styling highly prescriptive: h1-h6 fonts/sizes/weights/tracking all defined, list markers colored, blockquotes styled with left border accent
Seasons Sans font (12 weights including non-standard) is configured but 'DM Mono' has no @font-face (external CDN dependency, likely Google Fonts)
Nested `:is(.gml-primarycolumn, .report-prose)` selector allows dual use of prose styling for both GML and exported reports
key_signals: Tailwind v4 CSS-first: @layer theme with 277 custom properties
Dual color model: OKLCH (22 hue families) + Hex (neutrals/semantic/errors)
Redesign theme: data-theme='redesign' attribute switches fonts (Geist→Seasons Sans), colors (OKLCH→HSLA alpha), shadows (complex→simple)
Custom shadow 3-tier: low/low-hover/high, pragmatically mapped to TW scale
GML prose styling: h1-h6 + p/list/blockquote/table all prescribed (no component library freedom)

primary_topic: Complete Tailwind v4 theme extraction from SuperAgent CSS bundle — 277 color variables, shadow system, typography scale, animations
design_decisions_found: Color palette: 22 standard Tailwind families (red-rose) in OKLCH, custom primary/error/warning/success in Hex
Shadow system: 6-layer multi-shadow for depth (low/low-hover/high tiers), 13 keyframes (fadeSlideIn, pulse-scale, accordion, shimmerLine, etc.)
Typography: Geist variable font (100-900 weight), Seasons Sans for redesign theme, DM Mono for monospace
Custom utilities: z-index scale (10 levels), perspective distances, aspect ratios, container queries
Easing functions: cubic-bezier presets for transitions, Framer Motion easings (linear, easeInOut)
schemas_or_data: 277 CSS custom properties: --color-{red,orange,amber,...,rose,slate,gray,zinc,stone}-{50,100,...,950}
Custom properties: --z-index-modal (50), --z-index-dropdown (40), --z-index-tooltip (30)
Font stack: Geist (variable), Seasons Sans (redesign, 12 weights), DM Mono (fallback external)
Animation keyframes: fadeSlideIn (highlight flash), pulse-scale (2 variants), shimmerLine, accordion-down/up, infinite-slide
Container queries: @container (width >= 28rem) for @md rules, (width >= 48rem) for @3xl rules
key_insights: Tailwind v4 CSS-first means no config file; all tokens defined in @layer theme block (simpler, but less tooling support for design-to-code workflows)
Custom keyframes suggest deliberate animation strategy beyond standard TW (fadeSlideIn for report generation feedback, pulse-scale for loaders)
Container queries provide responsive design without viewport breakpoints — components scale to their container, not page width (better for modular UI)
Seasons Sans font with 12 weights (including non-standard 440, 550, 580, 650) suggests high-fidelity type specification (not just 400/700)
Z-index scale suggests no CSS-in-JS or component library z-index management — all layers explicit and centralized
key_signals: Tailwind v4 CSS-first @layer theme: 277 custom properties, no config file
OKLCH primary palette (22 families) + Hex semantic (errors, warnings, success)
Custom animations: fadeSlideIn, pulse-scale-mini, shimmerLine, accordion-down/up, infinite-slide
Seasons Sans proprietary font with 12 weights (non-standard intermediates)
Container queries @md (@28rem) and @3xl (@48rem) replace viewport breakpoints

primary_topic: JavaScript bundle token extraction — design tokens, Plotly schemas, Zod schemas for streaming events, CVA component variants, chart color palettes
design_decisions_found: Plotly.js as primary charting library in chat UI (vs Recharts in exports); 10 chart type schemas with Zod validation
HSLA color palette hardcoded in JS (not CSS variables): 6-stop teal, green accent, red error gradients
CVA (class-variance-authority) for component variant management: status badges (good/bad/warning/neutral), source pills, toasts
22 NDJSON streaming event types (discriminated union): stream_start, task_update, node_tool_event, node_report_preview_*, message_delta, references_found, etc.
Phosphor Icons as primary icon library (vs Lucide in exports)
schemas_or_data: HSLA chart palette: 6-stop teal (186° hue), green accent (103°), red error with alpha variants
Plotly schemas: eD (data trace), eR (layout), eS (x-axis), ez (y-axis), eM (chart object with citation)
Streaming event union: 22 discriminated types with payload schemas (Status, SourceType, PendingSource, StreamEnvelope)
CVA variants: color (good/bad/neutral/warning), variant (web-unselected, document-selected, etc.), size (sm/md/lg)
Sentiment colors hardcoded: #E6FCE8 (good bg), #006400 (good text), #FFF2FA (bad bg), #B10F41 (bad text), #FFF6DD (warning bg), #AF6002 (warning text)
key_insights: Plotly.js in chat UI, Recharts in exports — dual charting strategy for different delivery contexts (streaming preview vs static export)
HSLA colors hardcoded in JS suggest either: (a) dynamic color generation not feasible in CSS-only, or (b) performance optimization for chart rendering
22 streaming event types prove sophisticated orchestration (not just chat streaming) — plan creation, task progress, tool execution, content synthesis, entity creation
Sentiment colors are semantic, not theme-aware — hard-coded hex suggests no theming for chart components (unlike GML components)
Phosphor Icons (6 weight variants) provide consistent icon styling across chat UI, different from exported report fonts
key_signals: Plotly.js (10 chart types) in chat, Recharts in exports, no D3 in chat UI
HSLA color palette: 6-stop teal (186°), green accent (103°), red gradients with alpha
22 NDJSON streaming event types: plan/task/tool lifecycle + content delta + entity creation
CVA for component variants: status badges (sentiment-colored), source pills (type-based), toasts
Sentiment colors hardcoded per type: good=#006400, bad=#B10F41, warning=#AF6002, neutral=#41454D

primary_topic: Reverse-engineered generation pipeline — 7-stage process from research/RAG to atomic export, multi-agent execution proof, output limits
design_decisions_found: Pipeline stages: Research/RAG → Template assembly → Architecture decision → Theme generation → Layout primitives → Content sections → Widget generation → Atomic export
Frozen 181K template bundle shipped to all reports (reports B & C identical byte-for-byte) regardless of utilization (85% unused components)
Multi-agent execution: Report A git history shows 4 named agents (A/B/C/D) working in parallel on feature branches (standards → 4 executors → integration)
Atomic export: all files written simultaneously (identical timestamp), not interactive development
Output ceiling: ~550K total output (~350K generated TSX), suggesting per-component or total token budget
schemas_or_data: Report architecture progression: A (monolithic 997 LOC) → B (coordinator 567 LOC) → C (pure imports 30 LOC)
Template bundle contents: 57 shadcn components, 8 custom SuperAgent additions, 45 modified stock, 5 unchanged stock
Multi-agent execution phases (Report A): Phase 1 (standards) → Phase 2 (4 parallel agents) → Phase 3 (integration), ~100 seconds each
Widget size distribution (Report C): 8 of 10 widgets between 506-685 lines (uniform output budgeting)
key_insights: v0.app is the code generation engine; SuperAgent is the orchestrator managing data flow and architecture decisions
Frozen template eliminates per-report template generation overhead (faster, more consistent), shipped as atomic blob
Multi-agent execution in Report A (git-tracked) proves capability, but Reports B/C use single-pass or hidden parallelism (atomic exports hide internal timing)
Output ceiling ~550K suggests either: (a) LLM token budget per generation, or (b) practical file size limit for zipped export
Widget size uniformity (8 of 10 in 506-685 LOC range) indicates per-component output budgeting, likely enforced via system prompt
key_signals: 7-stage pipeline: Research → Template → Architecture → Theme → Primitives → Sections → Widgets → Export
Frozen 181K template bundle (byte-identical B & C), 57 components, 8 custom SuperAgent additions
Multi-agent execution: Report A shows 4 parallel agents (standards → executors → integration phases)
Atomic export: all files same timestamp, no build artifacts, no node_modules/ or .next/
Output ceiling ~550K total (~350K generated), widget sizes 506-685 LOC (uniform budgeting)

primary_topic: Deep dive into Report C (AAPL/MSFT/GOOG Strategic Market Intelligence) — four-tier architecture, Soft Brutalism design system, 10 interactive widgets, react-simple-maps for geography
design_decisions_found: Four-tier architecture: ui/ → report/ → sections/ → widgets/ (cleaner separation than Report B's two-tier)
Soft Brutalism design: offset shadows (4px 4px 0px, hover press effect), geometric SVG patterns, Royal Blue primary + muted orange accent
11 report primitives + 8 section compositions + 10 widgets (total 5,929 LOC for interactive visualizations)
react-simple-maps for geographic heat map (first use of map library), Recharts for all other charts (no D3)
100% Recharts charting strategy (simpler than Report B's Recharts+D3 hybrid)
schemas_or_data: 10 widgets: competitive-matrix (scatter), dynamic-financial-chart (line/composed), scenario-planner (area/bar/radar), customer-persona-explorer (radar), investor-sentiment-dashboard (bar/line), geographic-heat-map (map+recharts), risk-assessment-dashboard (bar/radar), tech-evolution-timeline (custom SVG), esg-scorecard (bar/radialbar), financial-ratios-table (HTML)
Design tokens: #1e3a8a (Royal Blue), #ea580c (muted orange), #0d9488 (deep teal), #f97316 (muted orange light), container surfaces (elevated/sunken/hero)
Section variants: default (white), royal (blue bg, white text), dark (gray bg, white text), sunken (#f1f5f9)
Typography: Inter (sans), Space Grotesk (display), IBM Plex Mono (code)
key_insights: Four-tier architecture is evolution toward cleaner separation of concerns (ui primitives → report layout → section composition → widget implementation)
Soft Brutalism (offset shadows + geometric patterns) is distinct design language, not grid variation of Report B
100% Recharts (no D3) suggests v0.app learning or user preference — simpler maintenance, consistent API
react-simple-maps integration proves capability for domain-specific visualization (not just generic charts)
Uniform widget sizing (8 of 10 between 506-685 LOC) strongly suggests per-component system prompt template enforcing consistent output
Data consistency across 5+ files (MSFT $281.7B, AAPL $416.2B) proves shared data brief, not embedded generation per-widget
key_signals: Four-tier: ui → report → sections → widgets (evolution from Report B's two-tier)
Soft Brutalism design: offset shadows (4px), hover press effect, geometric SVG patterns
10 widgets, 100% Recharts (no D3), react-simple-maps for geography
Section variants: default/royal/dark/sunken (evolved from Report B's boolean alternate)
Data consistency: MSFT $281.7B in 5+ files proves shared brief, not per-widget generation

primary_topic: Font and external asset extraction — Seasons Sans proprietary font family (12 weights), Geist Mono, external CDN URLs, DM Mono
design_decisions_found: Seasons Sans (ATSeasonSans) — proprietary font from A-Type foundry, 12 weights including non-standard (300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, and italic variants)
Custom font weights (440, 550, 580, 650) not in standard CSS weight scale suggest bespoke type specification (not generic font family)
Two-tier font strategy: Geist (base UI, variable font 100-900), Seasons Sans (redesign theme, fixed weights)
External asset dependencies: Geist from Vercel CDN, Seasons Sans from /static/font/, DM Mono from external source (likely Google Fonts, no @font-face)
schemas_or_data: Seasons Sans weights/styles: 300/400/500/600/700/800 × normal/italic (12 @font-face declarations)
Geist variable font: single file with 100-900 weight range
External asset URLs: 19 CDN/analytics/API endpoints tracked
Font file serving: Vercel asset CDN with content-hash filenames (e.g., _next/static/font/...)
key_insights: Seasons Sans 12-weight specification is unusually comprehensive (most fonts use 4-6 weights) — suggests high design fidelity requirement or A-Type foundry contract
Non-standard weights (440, 550, 580, 650) imply font was custom-commissioned or subset (not off-the-shelf)
DM Mono has no @font-face declaration (external dependency) — may be Google Fonts or other CDN, not self-hosted
Font files served from Vercel asset CDN with content-hash naming (immutable, cache-friendly, production-grade setup)
Two-tier font strategy (Geist base, Seasons Sans redesign) enables thematic switching via data-theme attribute
key_signals: Seasons Sans: proprietary A-Type foundry font, 12 weights including non-standard intermediates
Geist variable font (100-900) for base UI, DM Mono for code (external CDN)
Custom weights (440, 550, 580, 650) suggest bespoke type specification or foundry contract
Vercel CDN with content-hash filenames (immutable, cache-friendly)
Two-tier: Geist (base) + Seasons Sans (redesign) switchable via data-theme attribute

primary_topic: Current state of DocuIntelli platform build — what exists end-to-end, gaps vs Superagent, architectural choices already made
design_decisions_found: Substrate layer working: content-addressed artifacts, immutable manifests, mutable pointers (bundle semantics)
LangGraph research assistant graph exists (single agent, doc-grounded Q&A with tool-use loop)
Run ledger + SSE streaming for run events (Postgres LISTEN/NOTIFY) already in place
Two distinct streaming paths: AI SDK SSE for chat, platform SSE for run events
Deliverable gaps: no report/slides/website/document generators yet
schemas_or_data: Backend services: Substrate (artifacts/manifests/pointers), Runs+RunLedger (SSE streams), RAG (Docling PDFs, OpenSearch/pgvector), Sessions, Conversations, Tags
LangGraph research assistant: ToolNode with search_documents, list_notebooks, get_document_info, compare_manifests tools
SSE streaming: two paths (chat via Vercel AI SDK, run events via Postgres LISTEN/NOTIFY)
key_insights: Intelli kernel is working and proven, but product layers (deliverables, multi-agent orchestration) are gaps vs Superagent
Run ledger exists but not yet mapped to plan/node/tool hierarchy that Superagent uses
Two-stream architecture (chat + run events) is good foundation but requires UI unification (Sources/Files/Activity panes)
No multi-agent planner yet — single agent loop is limiting vs Superagent's planner→executors→synthesizer
key_signals: Substrate layer working: artifacts, manifests, pointers (content-addressed)
LangGraph single-agent research loop in place (doc-grounded Q&A)
SSE streaming: dual paths (chat + run events) enable future UI integration
Gaps: no multi-agent orchestration, no deliverable generators, no rich markup (vs Superagent's GML)
Two-stream design (chat + run events) is foundation for Sources/Files/Activity panes

primary_topic: Six-phase plan to achieve Superagent parity on Intelli — research orchestrator, entity/citation substrate, deliverables (report/slides/website), browser-use, HITL
design_decisions_found: Keep Intelli kernel (substrate, run ledger) as source of truth; use LangGraph for orchestration
Adopt NYQST Markup v1 (clean-room GML equivalent) for deliverables — JSON AST recommended over HTML-like tags
Unify Sources/Files/Activity around existing primitives: sources (artifacts), files (manifest entries), activity (run ledger)
Phased approach: orchestration events → entity/citation → web research → deliverables v1 (report+doc) → deliverables v2 (slides+website) → browser-use/HITL
schemas_or_data: Phase 1: RunEvent schema extensions for plan/node/tool hierarchy + PlanViewer UI component
Phase 2: Entity model (WEB_PAGE, EXTERNAL_API_DATA, GENERATED_REPORT, etc.) + citation resolver API
Phase 3: Web research tools (Brave Search, Firecrawl/Jina scrape, domain allowlist search)
Phase 4: Deliverable record type + NYQST Markup v1 + renderer + artifact exports (PDF/DOCX)
Phase 5: Slides (PPTX) + Website (static bundle) generators
Phase 6: Browser automation service (Playwright-based) + interrupt/resume endpoints + UI
key_insights: Clean-room approach: no Superagent IP copying, but observable-capability parity via reverse engineering
JSON AST for markup (not HTML-like tags) chosen for easier validation and healing vs regex-based parsing
Web research providers (Brave, Firecrawl, Tavily) are modular — can hot-swap based on policy/cost
Deliverable phasing prioritizes report first (highest user value, exercises full pipeline), then breadth (slides, website)
Browser-use deferred to Phase 6 (lowest priority, most complex), but can start in parallel with other phases
key_signals: Six phases: orchestration → entities/citations → web research → deliverables v1 → deliverables v2 → browser-use/HITL
NYQST Markup v1 (JSON AST, not HTML-like tags) for rich deliverables (cleaner validation/healing)
Web research providers: Brave/Firecrawl/Jina (modular, hot-swappable)
Deliverable priorities: Report → Document → Slides → Website → Browser-use
Unify Sources/Files/Activity around substrate/runledger primitives

primary_topic: Technical mapping for research orchestrator — extends LangGraph with planner node, parallel subagents, fan-out/fan-in pattern, run event schema extensions
design_decisions_found: Research orchestrator graph: planner → fan_out_research → [parallel_research_nodes] → fan_in_results → synthesizer → deliverable
Planner node: takes user prompt, generates structured PlanSet output (Pydantic model matching Superagent)
Fan-out via LangGraph Send() API for parallel dispatch of research subgraph invocations
RunEvent schema extensions: PLAN_CREATED, SUBAGENT_STARTED/PROGRESS/COMPLETED, CONTENT_DELTA, ARTIFACT_CREATED, CLARIFICATION_NEEDED
Option A recommended: store plans as RunEvents with structured payloads (no new tables), not separate plans/plan_tasks tables
schemas_or_data: Planner node output: PlanSet { plans: Record<string, Plan>, chat_id, workspace_id }, Plan { plan_tasks: Record<string, PlanTask>, status, used_sources[] }
New RunEventType enums: PLAN_CREATED, SUBAGENT_STARTED, SUBAGENT_PROGRESS, SUBAGENT_COMPLETED, CONTENT_DELTA, ARTIFACT_CREATED, CLARIFICATION_NEEDED
Web research MCP tools: research.web.search (Brave API), research.web.scrape (Jina/Firecrawl), research.web.domain_search (allowlist-filtered)
Testing strategy: contract tests (Pydantic schema validation), integration tests (real LLM calls), E2E tests (Playwright UI flow)
key_insights: Planner node enforces structured output via Pydantic (not free-form LLM text), enabling downstream graph orchestration with confidence
Fan-out pattern in LangGraph is well-documented, simpler than custom worker pools
Option A (RunEvents for plans) preserves append-only semantics and avoids schema duplication (run ledger IS the plan history)
Web research tools are MCP servers (external) or internal tools (simpler, same effect), enabling hot-swap providers
Testing strategy includes contract tests (schema validation) and integration tests (real LLM), not just unit tests
key_signals: LangGraph StateGraph: planner → fan_out → parallel subagents → fan_in → synthesizer → deliverable
Planner node: structured PlanSet output via Pydantic, creates RunEvent for plan creation
Fan-out via LangGraph Send() for parallel dispatch
RunEvent schema: PLAN_CREATED, SUBAGENT_STARTED/PROGRESS/COMPLETED, CONTENT_DELTA, ARTIFACT_CREATED
Web research tools: Brave Search, Jina/Firecrawl scrape, domain allowlist filtering

primary_topic: PropSygnal Document Intelligence Module specification — provenance-first knowledge platform for real estate; normative intelligence; ontology governance; decision procedures
design_decisions_found: Provenance-first design (W3C PROV-DM aligned): every data point traces to source document/section/clause
Hohfeld + defeasible deontic logic for normative representation (rights, duties, permissions, exceptions, overrides)
Ontology governance: 5-tier hierarchy (portfolio → org approved → org working → proposed → library) with strict precedence
Bi-temporal versioning: nothing deleted, full time-travel queries enabled
Organization Intelligence via runtime learning (OIB): learn org-specific definitions from existing artifacts
schemas_or_data: DocumentNode: document/section/paragraph/sentence/table/cell/page hierarchy with position tracking (character offset, page number)
HypergraphEdge: contains/references/depends_on/version_of/conceptual edge types with confidence and evidence refs
ContentEntity: business entities (Property, Contract, Agent, Transaction) with provenance tracking (documentId, nodeId, extractionMethod, confidence)
NormativePosition (Hohfeld-aligned): RIGHT/DUTY/PRIVILEGE/NO_RIGHT/POWER/LIABILITY/IMMUNITY/DISABILITY with deontic modality (obligation/prohibition/permission/waiver)
ObligationInstance: DORMANT/ACTIVE/FULFILLED/BREACHED/CURED/REMEDIED/WAIVED/SUPERSEDED/EXPIRED with temporal tracking and evidence
key_insights: PropSygnal is NOT the Intelli platform itself, but a domain-specific 'Lease CD' module (one of three initial domain modules per Intelli strategy)
Provenance tracing and normative intelligence are platform capabilities that Lease CDs exercise (contracts are fundamentally normative)
Defeasible deontic logic models real-world contract complexities ('except where...', 'subject to...', 'notwithstanding...')
OIB (runtime learning) eliminates consulting bottleneck by inferring org-specific definitions from existing documents/models
Ontology tiers ensure governance without rigid schema lock-in (library → working → proposed allows org evolution)
key_signals: Provenance-first design (W3C PROV-DM): every fact traceable to source clause
Hohfeld + defeasible deontic: model contracts as normative systems with exceptions and overrides
5-tier ontology governance: portfolio → org approved → org working → proposed → library (strict precedence)
Bi-temporal versioning: nothing deleted, time-travel queries enabled
OIB (org intelligence builder): runtime learning from existing artifacts eliminates consulting

design_decisions_found: Three parallel agent branches (agent-first-doc-intelligence, async-ui-components-setup, cre-intelligence-workflows) successfully merged into single branch preserving all commits
217 unique files across 3 branches merged without losing history (deduplication handled correctly)
Merge conflicts resolved (e.g., .gitignore consolidation)
schemas_or_data: Branch file counts: Agent 1 (119 files, 117 unique), Agent 2 (67 files, 65 unique), Agent 3 (34 files, 33 unique); total unique = 217
Merge strategy: create local branch from main, merge the three remote branches sequentially (Option 1 recommended), preserving history
key_insights: Three-agent parallel development pattern executed successfully (agents worked independently, merged cleanly)
Cursor can automate requirements extraction from branches (Python tool discussed to extract explicit/implicit requirements, conflicts, commonalities, patterns)
Merge deduplication worked correctly (220 file count across branches - 3 duplicates = 217 unique files in merged result)
key_signals: Three parallel agent branches (doc-intelligence, async-ui, cre-workflows) merged cleanly into single branch
217 unique files across all three branches, merge conflicts resolved
Capability: automated requirements extraction from parallel branches (explicit + implicit + conflicts + patterns)
Preserve history pattern: create new branch from base, merge three remote branches sequentially
